description.narrative: AFSA har hos Sida ansökt om finansiering av 49 000 000 kronor för genomförandet av "Making sexual and reproductive health rights real in South Africa Project " under perioden 2014-2017. Projektet syftar till att uppmärksamma och förändra sociala och kulturella strukturella hinder samt att identifiera och förmå besluts fattare att avhjälpa de systemfel som förhindrar förverkligandet av hiv/aids och SRH rättigheter i marginaliserade samhällen och grupper. Programmet är utformat för att: 1. Ge strategiskt stöd till lokala organisationer inom civila samhället (CBOs) och nationella aktörer i Sydafrika inom politik och lobbying som engagerar sig i effektiva hiv/aids och SRHR-insatser. 2. Påvisa förbättringar i förverkligandet av SRHR i Sydafrika 3. Erbjuda ett mätbart bidrag till kunskapen och faktabasen om hiv/aids och SRHR i södra Afrika. AFSA kommer att genomföra insatsen tillsammans med 18 organisationer inom civilsamhället, till vilka de kommer erbjuda ekonomiskt och tekniskt stöd.

AFSA has applied to Sida for funding of 49 000 000 SEK to carry out the 'Making sexual and reproductive health rights real in South Africa Project' during the period 2014-2017. The Project aims to address and catalyse the transformation of social and cultural structural barriers and to identify and compel duty bearers to redress the systemic failures, which impede the realisation of HIV/AIDS and SRH rights in marginalised communities and populations. The programme is designed to deliver: 1. strategic support for community-based organisations (CBOs) and national policy/advocacy actors engaged in effective HIV & AIDS and SRHR interventions in South Africa. 2. demonstrable improvements in the realisation of SRHR in South Africa. 3. a measurable contribution to the knowledge and evidence base on HIV & AIDS and SRHR in the Southern Africa region.
AFSA will implement the intervention together with 18 civil society organisations to whom it will offer financial and technical support through sub-granting.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative:
General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2017Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: The AIDS Foundation of South Africa (AFSA) began implementation of the Swedish funded Sexual and Reproductive Health Rights programme in May 2014. The programme is titled Making Sexual and Reproductive Health Rights Real in South Africa. The primary goal of this programme was to catalyse and build momentum to transform social, cultural and structural barriers, together with systemic failures that currently impeded the realisation of Sexual and Reproductive Health Rights within targeted locations in South Africa.
This programme was designed to deliver: 1. Strategic support for community based organisations (CBOs) and national policy/advocacy actors engaged in effective SRHR interventions; 2. Demonstrate improvements in the realisation of SRHR in South Africa; 3. A measurable contribution to the knowledge and evidence base on HIV & AIDS and SRHR in the Southern Africa region.
AFSA was the principal recipient and implemented the programme in partnership with strategically selected five non-government organisations operating at national and ten local level/ community based organisations in Eastern Cape, KwaZulu Natal, Free State and Mpumalanga provinces. In an external evaluation of the Project, that was commissioned to look at the extent to which the programme outcomes were achieved by AFSA and its partners between May 2014 and December 2016 a number of notable achievements were highlighted. These include the projects ability to: - provide valuable capacity building and organisational development support all sub recipients - provide a platform to CBO and NGO partners to network and create linkages where there are SRHR issues of similar interest or support needed - enable strategic partnerships to be formed with government institutions such as healthcare facilities and social development. As a result programme partners such as Section 27 and TAC engaged at the highest level of government both at National level for example. Department of Health and South African National AIDS Council (SANAC) as well as at the Provincial level, on issues such as drug stock outs, provision and access to health services and development of the National Strategic Plan (NSP). - enable CBO partners to use the Sida funding to leverage additional resources from other funders in order to expand and scale up interventions and ensure sustainability of these interventions - to identify local solutions for local challenges and problems through the research component.
Overall the intervention has been able to lay the foundation for both CBO and NGO partners to collectively work together on common issues, so as to achieve a greater impact when it comes to advocating for the realization of SRHR in South Africa.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
